title: The Skiers

children.value:
Two skiers want to reach the top of an incline without pushing. The first skier, of mass 
$\vari{m}$
, reaches the start of the incline with a speed 
$\vari{v}$
. He just makes it to the top of the incline. The second skier, of mass 
$\vari{\frac{2}{3}m}$
, has a speed 
$\vari{\frac{2}{3}v}$
 at the bottom of the incline. Will she make it to the top without pushing? It can be assumed that frictional forces are negligible.

choices.value: Yes, she makes it to the top with a non-zero velocity
Yes, she just makes it to the top

answer.value:
The correct answer is (b). This can be seen by conserving energy; the initial $\valuedef{h}{\frac{v^{2}}{2g}}{}$ and the second height would be $\valuedef{h_{2}}{\frac{2v^{2}}{9}}{}$ = $\vari{\frac{4}{9}h}$ .

Motion where gravitational potential is the only energy loss is independent of mass, since the $\vari{m}$ cancels out in $\valuedef{\frac{1}{2}mv^{2}}{mgh}{}$ .
